case_vignette: A 6-month-old baby boy presents to his pediatrician for the evaluation of recurrent bacterial infections. He is currently well but has already been hospitalized multiple times due to his bacterial infections. His blood pressure is 103/67 mm Hg and heart rate is 74/min. Physical examination reveals light-colored skin and silver hair. On examination of a peripheral blood smear, large cytoplasmic vacuoles containing microbes are found within the neutrophils.
question: What diagnosis do these findings suggest?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My baby has been getting sick with bacterial infections often and has been in the hospital multiple times because of them.

I see. Is your baby under 2 years old? (Immune system development continues until around age 2)

**Final Diagnosis:**: Primary Immunodeficiency (most likely Severe Combined Immunodeficiency - SCID)

(Note: This diagnosis is based on the provided information and further tests are required for confirmation.)

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient has been experiencing frequent bacterial infections and has had multiple hospitalizations as a result. The patient's most recent infection has resulted in painful sores on their penis and swelling in their left groin, which began 10 days ago. The patient, who is 22 years old, has not had symptoms like this before. Their female partner was diagnosed with chlamydia last year, but the patient has not been checked for it. They have no other medical conditions and are not taking any medications. There is no family history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases in the patient's case.

trial_3.summarized_mcq: Chediak-Higashi syndrome. This is a rare genetic disorder characterized by recurrent bacterial infections, low levels of certain types of white blood cells, and pigmentary abnormalities. It is caused by mutations in the LYST gene, leading to impaired intracellular transport and function of lysosomes. This results in the characteristic oculocutaneous albinism, as well as increased susceptibility to infections.
